commit.message:
CLI startup disabling GUI is now temporary and not marked changed.
CLI startup disabling itself is now temporary and not marked changed.
Started work on immediate saving of config changes (not yet active).

CLI startup show/hide gui or cli no longer permanent but
changes made in 'settings' still are.
small iterrim updates

Added missing .xiy file needed for Dooo Flute.
Added True Drawbars instrument.
Updated User Guide.

Added more instruments to Drums and Noises
Updated User Guide
System effect sends now show percentages
MIDI CCs now show percentages
Master window volume panning velocity show real values
    Velocity offset still not done

**Reverted previous change**

There were some controls in the instance data that were
needed by LV2 at startup.

Split off config state loading from LV2
Previously, from LV2 we were loading saved instance data (if it existed)
then for an existing project overwriting this with the LV2 saved data.
If it was a completely new instance it would in any case start with the
default config so this was quite pointless.

BugFix: "Enable Single Master" accesssable on secondary instances.
Removed (now redundant) disabled code from SynthEngine.cpp
Also removed long unused SSE code from Config.cpp

BugFix: CLI not recognising 'type' returned by limits code.
There may still be some CLI anomalies.

BugFix: Master detune not identified as float type.
This prevented the CLI making small incremental changes.

BugFix: CLI not checking XML copmpression range.
Forced type to integer for all CLI config tests.
CLI should be checking this for all values via Limits.

Moved config limits from SynthEngine.cpp to Config.cpp but these
don't seem to be used anywhere.

Created new files Interchange/Vector.cpp & Interchange/Vector.h
Transferred Load, Save, and Limits to these and commented out
SynthEngine versions. Will leave these in place for further testing.

Also found CLI wasn't checking Limits so corrected this for major
controls. This needs more work to check the remainder.

Small changes to make Yoshimi's name definition more consistent.
This is defined in CMakeLists.txt and given the label: YOSHIMI
Some parts of the code were using this while others directly entered
"Yoshimi". The more significant ones have now been changed. Not sure
about some of the others so left them alone.

Merged in new GUI/core interface from Hermann
Cleaned up some doccumentation
Set CMakeLists for (usually) faster GUI compilation

Merge pull request #200 from Ichthyostega/guiconnect

Gui-connect-1

commit.message:
[guiconnect] - documentation and clean-up of prototype code

GuiDataExchangeTest : this is a demonstration prototype used to draft the system
                      moved it to dev_notes for later referral

GuiDataExchange.txt : a summary of concepts and high-level explanation of the implementation

Statrtup_Synth_instances.txt : documentation of findings how the various instances
                      of the SynthEngine are started and operated.

[guiconnect] - adapt the LV2 plugin to employ the new UI-start scheme

This solution works, but is not entirely correct,
since we generate a new UI-Anchor directly from the UI-Thread / Plugin-UI processing.
Thus we are missing a thread sync barrier towards the Synth / Plugin-Audio thread

In fact we do not know in which Thread the Synth-Object was created and
initialised by the LV2 plugin host. Actually, SynthEngine::publishGuiAnchor()
just generates a DTO and copies in the connection-IDs from the Synth-Object.

If this Synth-Object was created in another thread, there is the theoretical
possibility that some of these IDs were not yet published out of this thead's
CPU cache. While I should add, that in practice this seems highly unlikely.

[guiconnect] - switch EQ graph to a LUT delivered by push-update

Note: the old version used to call into the core for each pixel
with a frequency matched exactly to this pixel; with this changeset,
rather the draw() code uses local data from a table, which has the
downside that we have to interpolate between adjacent prepared
sample values. For very sharp peak/notch filters this can lead to
an unprecise, "wobbly" curve. The density of the LUT can be controlled
by the constant EQ_GRAPH_STEPS in Effect.h -- but beware: we send a float
for each point; so huge number of points ==> huge data block ==> an even
larger memory buffer must then be set aside for all the slots used by
GuiDataExchange. So this clearly is a trade-off

[guiconnect] - prepare for push-updates of EQ graph

- Include the push-update to the MirrorData block in the EQ graph
  whenever the effect is actually an EQ.
- extract the scale transformation functions and relocate them
  into the EQ module itself; for the push-update the EQ itself
  will have to pre-render a Lookup-Table to represent the graph

[guiconnect] - a hack to force updates after load-by-config

While the previous changes provided fairly complete coverage of update situations
relevant to the effects, it left an open gap when changes happen /before GUI startup/

Notably this is the case when loading content per configuration or commandline
-l, --load=<file>
-L, --load-instrument=<file>[@part]
-S, --state[=<file>]

Even when push-updates are published in those cases, those messages will
not be delivered, rather silently discarded, because there is no receiver(yet).

So actually we'd need a "post-GUI-startup hook";
the SynthEngine could then decide if parts of the GUI need additional data
and (re)send some push-updates.

As a first and rather cheesy workaround, this changeset adds such a hook,
but invokes it directly from the GUI thread (it should better be run from Synth)
And as a second, complimentary hack, the GUI is prompted to do a refresh,
in order to make the received data visible. This is achieved by sending
the MAIN::control::masterReset, but *only* to the GUI.

[guiconnect] - remove UI state regarding effect number and type

These UI state variables were used to perform an indexed access
directly into the Synth engine core. By removing those extraneous state
variables, the UI is no longer able to access the effect modules in the Core.

Rather, all usages were switched over to rely solely on the local values
sent per push-update and stored in the MirrorData block in the EffUI.
Notably this also removes the possiblility of core and UI state to get
mixed or confused; even after a command has been sent, the UI continues
to use the old values uniformely for all settings and parameters of that effect,
until the push-update arrives.

NOTE: A special twist with this changed scheme for UI connections
is that the core must now reliably issue a push-update whenever the
UI actually needs new or updated data. Failing to do so will leave
the UI with outdated state, since the UI does not actively pull data
from core any more.

Typically these updates should be attached to command processing,
because, as it stands, this is the most systematic way to know when
actually something happens or is changed in Yoshimi.

As an aside, I clarified the entrance point to the Unified Presets
(after I spent an hour searching where the heck the copy / paste
functionality is actually implemented; the old name "section()"
did not convey that it is actually a mutating operation)

[guiconnect] - provide additional effect control params via DTO

This is a preparation for the next step, attempting to get rid of
extraneous UI state related to the control parameters (effect number,
effect type, routing bypass). Rather, these shall be provided alongside
with the effect parameters in the Data Transfer Object.

Some casual clean-up:
- "short int" is an exotic data type nowadays and requires additional
  assembly to be emitted for arithmetic and to access a "packed" array.
  All existing usages convert to int or compare to int constants.
- the UI for the Part-effect routing has special case treatment for uchar(127),
  which is then mapped to the default setting (1 == route to part out).
  I can not see any justification for that in the existing usages. In Synth,
  this value is only ever checked against the fixed constants 0 ("Next Effect")
  or 2 ("Dry Out"). When reading from XML, the value is conformed 0 <= x < 3

[guiconnect] - switch complete EffUI from direct-access to using DTO data

This changeset even removes the EffMgr* from the UI.
Moreover, several abbreviations were introduced, to make the code more legible

- isBeatSync()
- isSepDelay()
- isInsert()
- effParam(n)
- effPreset()
- __setColor(widget, preset, idx)

NOTE: this is only a partial change, since other parts of the UI
still continue to access the core directly. This causes inconsistent
behaviour esp. in the Part-Effect, which will be addressed as next steps.
Moreover, the nested sub-displays are not yet adapted / switched to the
new system, and thus a "backdoor" is used to sneak in the direct pointer
into these sub components (-> DTO-field "eff_in_core_TODO_deprecated")

[guiconnect] - transfer effect data to DTO

Add the ability to the Effect interface to extract all parameters
by an bulk operation, thereby allowing to populate the DTO in one shot.
Most effect use <20 parameters, but the EQ is an "outlier", since it
exposes 5 settings per bank, making for a total of 45 parameters.

Used this as opportunity to introduce "override" markers into this
hierarchy; this is a good practice to prevent from accidentally
"detaching" some subclass virtual function from the interface.

[guiconnect] - extend push-update to handle part-effects as well

As it turns out, from within the component, part effects and
insert effects are indistinguishable, they are just initialised
by another Effect instance. The only tangible difference is the
handling of the selector and bypass widgets, which are not located
in the EffUI, but in the PartUI rather, and propagate to commandPart.

The code uses the partNr do encode the difference, making system effect
and global insert effect two special cases. Thus, following the same logic,
the push-update handler can be made generic and cover all three cases.

As an aside, this change fixes duplicate creation of PartUI

Seemingly related to
6c7a3061d

Yet in fact, PartUI will be automatically constructed by FLTK,
and thus the further initialisation code can be moved down to MasterUI::make_window().

Moreover, seemingly it is not necessary to add it manually to the partuigroup,
since this happens automatically when widgets are created before partuigroup->end()
Only the call to checkEngines() must happen after closing this ownership backet
and after the end of make_windows()

[guiconnect] - identify situations where to trigger a push update

After exhaustive analysis of the update mechanisms
it became clear that we have to care for two different situations

- a change of the currently exposed component in the GUI
- intrinsic data changes for effect parameters

It seems to fit best with the existing style of handling changes to attach
the push updates to the *command processing* (as opposed to attach it to
actual data changes). All relevant manipulations, either through UI widgets
or from the CLI will propagate to
 - InterChange::commandSysIns
 - InterChange::commandEffects

Using this approach, we have to care for some additional situations where
the Effect state is changes as result of global actions, like loading state.
Analysis of call graphs inidcates that these all boil down to loading data
from XML (with a sole exception, the SynthEngine::resetAll() function).
Moreover, no update is required from Init(), since the default state of the
GUI will be propagated correctly from a default constructed EffectDTO.

[guiconnect] - wire new connections for the Effect UI

This is a first attempt to introduce GuiDataExchange connections into UI components.
Unfortunately FLTK requires a fixed constructor signature for widgets;
thus we're forced to allow for (temporarily) uninitialised connections;
however, the plan is to have an init() call immediately after creating
the window or widget, so that we can effectively always assume an active connection.

So the wiring pattern introduced with this change set works as follows:

- in the SynthEngine (or some embedded component), for each GuiDataExchange "channel"
  a distinct connection object is created
- when the GUI starts up, SynthEngine::publishGuiAnchor() extracts
  the corresponding RoutingTags and places them into the InterfaceAnchor record,
  which is then sent per push-update into the GUI
- MasterUI creates the windows and invokes init()
- the EffUI::init() retrieves the suitable RuitingTag, combines them
  with a reference to GuiDataExchange and activates the MirrorData elements

Result:
- each EffUI instance has now a connected MirrorData<EffectDTO> in the field "effect"
- and the embedded EQGrap instance has likewise a MirrorData<EqGraphDTO> in the field "graph"

The next planned step will be to trigger a push-update on each relevant Effect/EQ change
After that we can start to switch from direct Core data access to using the
data in the MirrorData instances
[guiconnect] - optionally install a callback to be activated on-push

[guiconnect] - switch GUI start to bootstrap through GuiDataExchange

This is a bold change:
 - previously the GUI was hooked up onto a SynthEngine
 - now it gets a reference to InterChange and retrieves an
   initialisation record through the new GuiDataExchange system

Notably this initialisation record will transport any further connection IDs
into the GUI. This new arrangement allows to establish individual data connections
from components in the Synth into the corresponding UI Windows.

Moreover, this could be a first step towards the goal of retracting the Synth*
Instead of the GUI reaching through the synth* into the core, rather dedicated
configuration and data records could be pushed up into the GUI

[guiconnect] - integrate the new communication hub

- GuiDataExchange becomes a sub-component of Interchange
- thus, each SynthEngine indirectly holds now a GuiDataExchange
- it is wired with the toGUI ringbuffer to publish push-updates
- define a new InterfaceAnchor record, used to "bootstrap" the UI communication
- establish a wiring-and-initialisation function in SynthEngine,
  which will pick up all RoutingTags from sub-components in the engine
  and mark them into InterfaceAnchor; this allows the UI side in MasterUI
  to establish virtual 1:1 connections for all components involved in
  push-data exchanges
